habitat_description:
Northeast/Upper Midwest:
The Boreal chickadee is a permanent resident of boreal forests (Erskine 1977) and found in both young and mature coniferous forests, usually spruce (Picea spp.), sometimes balsam fir (Abies balsamea; Erskine 1977). Where fir is replaced by eastern hemlock (Tsuga canadensis), Black-capped Chickadee is more common than Boreal Chickadee, e.g., Algonquin Park in central Ontario (Erskine 1977). Usually rare in strictly deciduous vegetation, but occurs in mixed forests (Godfrey 1986, Cadman et al. 1987). Habitats utilized in Ontario more often wet than dry (Peck and James 1987). At southern limits of range, preference for spruce-fir forest still maintained, accounting for spotty distributions of this species in those regions (quoted directly from Ficken et al. 1996).

Northwest:
This species is found in spruce and fir stands east of Rocky Mtns. (Erskine 1977) but seemingly replaced by Black-capped chickadee in spruce forests of central British Columbia. Boreal Chickadee breeds throughout interior British Columbia, but mainly at higher elevations. In regions where other chickadee species occur, Boreal Chickadee always found at higher elevations, where it may overlap with Mountain Chickadee. In n. British Columbia, however, occupies variety of habitats, including open coniferous, deciduous, and mixed; not confined to higher elevations. Apparently absent from coastal British Columbia, where replaced by Chestnut-backed Chickadee. In northern part of range in Alaska, occurs in variety of habitats, including spruce and mixed spruce, alder (Alnus), and willow (Salix) (Gabrielson and Lincoln 1959, Irving 1960). Northern limit of species in Alaska coincides with northern limit of white spruce (Picea glauca)(quoted directly from Ficken et al. 1996).
